This game had such potential in the beginning. You could feel the creator's intent throughout the world. The days were spent searching for resources while skirting the territory of dangerous creatures. The nights were filled with terror, with storms and large jagged claws reaching out of the darkness. If you were caught without a shelter, survival was very difficult. The mechanics were solid and although the AI was a bit wonky, I'll never forget being lost in a sandstorm and attacked by those giant crabs. Going from this ragged existence to building vehicles felt very rewarding. Technology provided dominion over creatures that previously terrorized you, but this did not grant immunity to poor decisions, nor were you at the top of the food chain. It had a logical sense of progression and the tools you made were keys to access more distant and lucrative areas in the world map.

The developers abandoned this design and instead of expanding with more content and gameplay, chose to make everything more difficult and time consuming. Crafting became a chore and overly complex with no tangible reward to the time invested. The original map was thrown out and replaced with an awful mess that showed half a dozen ideas clearly not aware of each other and fighting for dominance over your inevitable buggy [software] death. 

Every now and then, I remember that magic of the original Osiris: New Dawn and check in on the latest reviews to see if things have turned around. For years, this sentimental notion was numbed by the familiar commentary on how buggy and incomplete it is. I can only hope other developers witnessed the origin of this game and carry the spark of genius it had to other creations in the future. By luck or design, it was a breathtaking insight into the evolution of the space survival genre. Many games have tried to emulate a space explorer marooned in a hostile and alien environment, piecing together bits of technology to gradually progress from survival to thriving on the land and reaching out to the stars once again. None I have seen hold such a unique and engaging atmosphere as this one did. To whoever played a part in creating this origin, thank you. 229.2 hours of invested hope signing off for good.

I will start by saying that this game shows promise for a sort-of open world survival game it is. But the problem with it, lies with bad design choices by the developer. Not lack of resources, time or pandering to the audience. 

Let's start by talking about the survival mechanics. There is food, water and both of your health meters - suit integrity and health. There is another meter for temperature but i have found that for the most part, you can just ignore this. Already, a bad design choice was to make simple intake of food and water difficult. In order to get water, you have to craft a glass container to get water from a lake. Or sap from a tree. You cant take water directly from the lake. You need a crafting station to build a vessel to accept the water! Then there is food. In order to obtain food, you must hack trees and plants and consume their leaves or attack monsters that MAY drop meat that needs to be cooked. The trouble with the latter is that many monsters push your camera up towards the sky, disorientating you. And the game is frequented by far, by the much deadlier monsters than can tear you apart without even trying. Bad design choice number 1. 

Moving on to the monsters, we have different variations from tiny little bug like creatures barely bigger than a roomba and all the way up to sand worms that are bigger than a skyscraper. I will talk about this in particular in a little while. There are flying monsters, crawling monsters, walking monsters and even ones that spit damaging stuff at the player. Another bad design choice is having these monsters wander around seemingly at random, with no goal or directive in mind. Sure, that wouldnt be a bad thing if they mostly kept to the areas that have resources needed for late game. Trouble is, they hang around early game resources too. Meaning, you can die trying to obtain the most basic of resources 10 minutes after starting the game. And you have no realistic way of defending yourself from these super large monsters until much, MUCH later in the game. Bad design decision number 2. 

A seperate section dedicated to the sand worm and it's problems. The concept of the sand worm is really great. The implementation of it, is just amatuerish. Why is this? Because it requires you know where they roam. Here is a point - they telegraph their arrival with rumbling, shaking camera and Dune style emerge from the ground far off in a big long arc directly aiming to land again right on top of you. For the most part, you can simply run to avoid them. But another bad design choice, which i will get into shortly, is movement is stifled by the ''small hops''. Move a tiny distance down a slope and you will ''hop'', land, come to a complete stop regardless of your forward momentum and require you to begin to move again. So now, a simple side step becomes impossible and the trajectory of the worm becomes impossible to avoid BECAUSE of the design of movement. And dont get me started on the horrendous jetpack. I played this game for dozens of hours some four years ago, back in 2017. It has been an EA title back then, same as it's now, and sadly playability hasn't improved much. A lot of people blame old devs for a lack of direction in developing the game, and praise the new ones for consistency. I fail to see anything that has changed in the game core for the better.

Looking at the progress of this game in ~5 years, I'm afraid it won't turn into anything sensible. That would most probably require redesigning the core gameplay into something more engaging mechanically, and it might be too late for such kind of a deep change.

Below is the breakdown of game aspects for anyone interested.

[h1]Survival aspects[/h1]
You have a health meter and a thirst and hunger ones. There are a range of renewable consumables in the game in the form of alien flora and fauna, and you can generally just chug anything and be done with this. Some buildings will allow you to cook more efficient foodstuff, but it doesn't give you much additional benefits, so overall the system doesn't feel satisfying.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Mobs are kind of okay-ish visually, but fighting them is a UX nightmare. Clipping into models is abundant. There are no mobs with ranged attack anymore - one mob could do that some 4 years ago, but looks like that ability was taken away. Melee is terrible, with strange hitboxes and unreliable damage output. On baseline difficulty mobs don't hit much damage-wise, and none of them feel dangerous at all, even a multi-story Goliath bug.

To top that off, mobs usually spawn right before your eyes a bit above ground. All of them in your vicinity usually aggro you as soon as you start gathering resources, so it's a constant boring and tedious fight with them.

There are pistols, rifles and whatnots, but crafting ammo for those is expensive and most weapons don't kick as much, so the bulk of combat boils down to running into a mob and clicking them to death. Shame.

[h1]Resources and crafting[/h1]
The recent game version, same as the old one, uses a combination of above-surface mineral nodes, gas geysers, pools of liquids and the occasional plant-based resources. These are scattered on the map, are static and, depending on your difficulty config, everything could be renewable. By default mineral nodes aren't, the rest is.

Minerals are gated through the hardness system, where you need to upgrade your mining implement to be able to collect higher-tiered resources. The bad thing is that there are some 10+ types of metals strewn around the map in large clusters, and you need to collect a lot of them to progress. Crafting involves smelting alloys, which means there's another 10+ of smeltables. Figuring out the list of raw resources to build something is on you - the game wouldn't break down a recipe for you, but you can at least pin some of the recipes to the HUD to track your progress.

In general the system is okay, but has become worse. Old version used mineral nodes with mixed mineral composition, so you could hunt for a specific pure nodes, or be content with a lower yield of something you needed. These days, you'll have to hunt for each and every material type independently, which feels like an unnecessary complication.

[h1]Base building[/h1]
Progression is gated via a couple of production buildings. There are different tiers (furnace > forge > printer > chemplant > fabricator > laboratory/garage), building them requires different tiers of resources and sometimes indoor space, which means building larger habitats. The usual game design thing. There's no incentive to build larger bases once you've got the progression unlocked.

Last update added an option to build an orbital station, and there's a way to construct modular buildings from blocks (instead of fully prefabed ones), but with no clear goal for those I didn't try that out.

[h1]Exploration[/h1]
There are currently three planets. A starting one is the most fleshed out, with a lot of asset reuse since the 4yo game version. It's an okay one, and the design for the props has always been okay in this game.

Once you've got a space ship constructed (that for some reason doesn't consume fuel, even though the humble rover eats hydrazine by the hectolitres), you can visit "orbit" - a static space above the first planet with a couple of rocks anchored and just sitting there motionless, - and fly and land onto two other planets.

These two planets are mostly placeholders. One mob type per planet and some extra resources thrown around. No points of interest, really. Exploring past the initial location is currently only necessary to get two higher-tier resources. Which you don't really need unless you want to try out some buildings and items that don't really have much application at this point as there's little extra content to explore.

Coupled with a clunky locomotion system where you would stumble against any sloped terrain, and a kind of inertial movement that's way to unresponsive for some, little is rewarding here.

[h1]Character progression[/h1]
Little of this is available. Your character has main XP bar, as well as profession-relevant XP bars. Filling the first gives you attribute points to spend on Strength, Stamina, Speed and HP, filling the rest awards you skillpoints for the specific profession trees.

While upon starting the game you can choose a class for your character, this is mostly cosmetic as it influences the initial pool of skill points. All characters are born equal, and profession skill trees don't offer specialization.

Old game version used to gate some items and buildings behind prerequisite profession skills you would need to buy out first. As of 2021, all profession skills are purely extra bonuses (e.g. mining speed, item durability etc) that you can live without.

TL;DR: Osiris is a very solid and promising open survival game for an EA title. It comes with many tools and toys to work towards that feel and sound great. Im pretty uneasy about EA titles, as i have a few in my library that are completely dead/money grabs. Seeing the trailers for this game and reading reviews, i was pretty skeptical. The trailers looked too good, and the reviews are mixed, which to me is a warning.

Starting off, you get to pick a class (basically a boost to parts of the tech tree to start with) and get some light character customization. After that, i dove into the big wide world.

Here i noticed the visuals/load times. The game looks great and loads quickly (max settings, and on an SSD). The trailer footage is on par with what i experienced graphics wise (not all the action stuff, but thats later). The sounds however were hit and miss.

The world and weather sound good. The impact from the enemies walking around (crab ones) were very well done, and the music/ambiance went hand in hand to build a leery atmosphere. All the menu sounds were pleasant as well.

 On the other hand, the starting tool was rather loud and obnoxious to use at first, and the player footsteps were somewhat inconsistent and made me think an enemy was close, when in fact it was my character shifting around while standing still. Hitting things in the face felt hefty and the rifle i made sounded outstanding after using a dingy blaster pistol.

Mechanics wise, the game hits all the boxes and does it pretty well. Starting with the good, the food and thirst are pretty fair. You dont have to stuff your face and chug gallons of liquid every second (Thank god) and you can get your hands on both with ease. Each food item had has diffrent values I.E: one fruit gives you food/water/heath, while another can give yout lots of food/water, but hurts you a bit. You can cook and farm, which is always welcome, and hunt (more or less).

The level mechanics are robust and sorta shallow at the same time. You get xp based on what your doing, which is awesome. EX: you build/salvage, you get engineer xp. You fight something, you get combat xp. You harvest a tree/bush, you get science exp. (some activities give you xp for multiple things) All that xp builds into points to spend in a straight forward tech tree. Each upgrade is impactful and meaningful (none of that add .1% to resist something BS) 

You also get personal xp to spend on your standard stam/health/speed/strength stuff. Each point makes a noticeable difference. I feel im in the midish/earlier stages, and have my tree about maxed (which saddens me, and is the shallow part) but my character still has a bit to go.

The main thing that pulls me to the genre is crafting/building. Osiris hits the nail on the head imo. I like to salvage and break stuff down, and build shiny cool toys. This game brings both to the table and brings alot. You can find busted bases and repair or break them down. Same goes for vehicles. I personally rebuilt a bio dome and a buggy. The process wasnt tedious and it felt quite fulfilling when i completed the repairs.

There are multiple milestones so to speak, when building up to gear and tech. The transition is decently paced, but can pull you in many directions. There was a point (after repairing a biodome) that i had to make a forge, which felt like a big deal, and was eager to make it. However, getting the mats for it felt daunting at the time, and was quite a jump up from the previous requirements. After awhile i got it done, and was greeted with a bunch of unlocks which felt quite rewarding, and gave me my next goals.

With crafting stations, most of them have multiple upgrade options, which i like. Each upgrade either adds more function, or makes a function less tedious. Each upgrade adds to the appearance to the station and gets "built on" with your tool. Just a nice touch and i note the extra mile taken here.

All of that above are some of the main positives for me. I could feel the love and hard work in all of it, and the dev has my respect.

Now for the negatives.. I would like to start by saying, these can change as i dont have alot of time put in (yet) but as of now, and also its EA. These are just my opinions from my 11 hours. Jumping in,

The combat is my biggest gripe. The different creatures all follow a similar pattern, and fighting them with melee, was not very enjoyable. By that time, i would have to dodge again, and repeat.

It could be in your face, point blank, but if the X is just even a little off, or your like, "in the creature because it doesnt know personal space", then its a miss. I got used to it, and moved on to guns, but it was extremely annoying.

 Dev, if you bothered to read this mass of txt. Please let me dive bomb on these scrubs by letting me swing during jumping/flight.

Another thing that drove me up the wall, was these MF's will follow you to the ends of the earth sometimes. I ran into my first giant crab monster, and after shitting my pants, i proceeded run the other way like my life depended on it. This thing followed me for 30 mins, and killed me twice. For one, my character was slow as balls, and once i ran low on oxygen, i couldnt sprint. I dove off a cliff and ran behind cover and crouched, but it was still dead locked onto me from a mile away. After awhile i ran to my hut thinking it would F off once i was inside. Nope, it plowed into my POS and wrecked my face. I respawned and it F'd me up a second time. Another thing i disliked is the way some of the "craft tables" work. I built a furnace, which is nice and all. I use it awhile, until i built a forge. Jumping from a ton of different stations, just to make one thing, for another station, was rather taxing.
